Ferdinand Gismund Albert Lemot Crosman Chorus Alizia Francisco Captain Sares Raymond Monsieur Davy Danisker Rabshake Gallop. Lar 2. Gent. Governor Sismund Agar Uoada Benwash the Jew Leiftenant Omnes/Both Ruben Sailors. 1st Officer 2nd Officer 1st son 2nd son Page Muffty Mulli 1st Sailor 2nd Sailor Surgeon Ianisa Turk UNK

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div2.stage: Enter Ward, Gismund, Albert, Ferd. Sailers rise from a Table.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: I will play no more.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
Set but my hand out, here is four hundred Crowns
unloosed yet, Fortune may make them yours.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
Fortune is a Bitch, a mere strumpet, she
hath turned up the Ace so long, I have never an eye
to see with, she hath soaked me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p:
We came aboard to venture with you,
Deal Merchant-like, put it upon one main,
And throw at all.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: One cast, and we will leave you.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.p: Leave us yet? we have a cast worth two of the rest.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: It is set, throw at it gentle Sir.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
We shall have time enough hereafter,
You are too violent.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
I fear you will not be half so forward anon when we
should use you.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: A sail, a sail, a sail.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Shout.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Why stand you so amazed? conceive you not the language
of the Sea?

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
Now you may show yourselves gamesters,
You shall have your bellies full of hazard.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: We are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Are you not Merchant-men?

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
How else? and deal by whole-sale, take up much at
a long day. Do you know this honourable shape? Heroic
Captain Ward, Lord of the Ocean, terror of Kings, Landlord
to Merchants, rewarder of Man-hood, conqueror of the
Western world, to whose followers the Lands and Seas pay
tribute, and they to none, but once in their lives to the manor
of Wapping, and then are free ever after. This is he my noble
mummers.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: We are for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
If it be our monies that you covet, willingly we
give it up, only deprive us not of our fair home, our Country:
do but land us.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Know we have other use for you,
Have not enticed you hither for your gold,
It is the man we want. Is it not a shame,
Men of your qualities and personage,
Should live as cankers, eating up the soil
That gave you being, like beasts that never look further
Than where they first took food, that men call home,
Which gives them means equal unto their minds,
Puts them in action.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
True, who is it would not smile
To hear a Soldier, that hath nothing left
But misery to speak him man, can show
More marks than pence, upon whose back contempt
Heaps on the weight of poverty. Who would not smile
To hear this piece of wretchedness boast his wounds?
How far he went to purchase them? with what honour
He put them on? and now for sustenance,
Want of a little bread, being giving up
His empty soul, should joy yet that his Country
Shall see him breath his last: when that air he terms his
Ungratefully doth stifle him.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
You tell us of a gulf, which to eschew,
You dash us gainst a rock more full of fear,
Of danger: for we should call that action,
Which gives unto posterity our name
Writ in the golden lines of honour, where this brands
Our fore-heads with the hateful name of thieves, of robbers.
Piracy, it is theft, most hateful, swallows up
The estates of Orphans, Widows, who borne free,
Are thus made slaves, enthralled to misery,
By those that should defend them, at the best.
You rob the venting Merchants, whose manly breast
Scorning base gain at home, puts to the main
With hazard of his life and state, from other lands
To enrich his own, whilst with ungrateful sands
He thus is overwhelmed.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
These children have been at Saint Antlins,
They will persuade us out of our profession.
A plague upon this Scholarship,
One man that savours of an University,
Is able to infect a whole Navy with cowardice.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
Cowardice? thou liest: there is not a man here dares
less than thyself.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p: Zounds I will try that.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Hold, or by all my hopes, who makes next proffer
Falls on my sword. If you will try your valours
The enemy is at hand. As for your virtuous lectures,
We are Mariners, and Soldiers, not tattered yet
Enough to hear them, though in time we might
Be apt for such tongue-comfort, being swayed
By your directions.
A sail, a sail, a sail.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: How? more sails yet?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p:
The first that we descried, doth bear a head,
And as it seems, pursued by a man of war,
They make with us for succour.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
Yes, we will succour her, and suck her too, as dry as
a Usurers palm.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Nay, then we are put from shore.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.p:
Without ken boys, more sails, the least delay.
O let us turn Serving-men, the trencher hold
Whilst others eat the meat.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Away, make ready for the fight.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.p:
Courage brave sparks, now to gain wealth, or graves:
To dye in peace fits beasts, and abject slaves.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Thou needst not fear the curse, bloodthirsty monster.
O that our better part should thus be captived
By sense and will! who like a ship unmanned,
That is borne by motion of the violent waves
And giddy winds, doth seem to make a course
Direct and punctive, till we see it dash
Against some prouder Sylla, and display
How much she inward wanted to her sway.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You have well described him: but to our own fortunes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
We must obey necessity, since it is our fates
To be surprised thus, by this monster beast.
We must as did that Captain, so much famed,
Lick the fierce Lyons feet, till happier times
Do give us freedom in his punished crimes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
You have well advised. Fortune in spite of thee,
However my body is thralled, my mind rests free.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
This stand our comfort: we may happen be
The Chorus only to their Tragedy.

div2.stage: Enter Lemot, his sister Alizia, putting on the weed of a Sailers boy, Monsieur Davy, and Sailers.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p:
Unfortunate sister, my heart dissolves to blood,
And pays sad tribute to thy sadder griefs.
Nay, make no period, our woes are not at full,
Hymen did never behold so black a nuptial.
Alas! with our delay we hasten misery,
See how they bear up to us. Dear sister hide
At least thy sex, though not thy sorrow.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
Wretched Alizia, little thinks young Raymond
His Bride is so near unto captivity.
Be gentle yet you seas, and swallow me,
Since I am denied his arms, let my virginity
Be offered unto him in sacrifice.
It will be some comfort, his love a maiden dies.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p:
Nay then thou cleavest my soul, do not distrust
Chaste thoughts are guided by a power, that is just.
My worthy friends, yet what persuasion needs
To stir up valour where necessity
And justice of our cause, in basest spirits
Would strike a fire to kindle cowardice?
Three days we have been pursued by a Dutch Pirate,
And now we are fallen upon no less a monster.
Methinks I see your eyes darting forth flames
Like Lyons in their chase, the greedy hunter
Seeming to warm that blood, whose heat and rage
Proves his destruction.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p:
Not ready yet? alas thou wilt betray
Thyself unto their lust.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
Rather to death: Nature this comfort gave,
No place so miserable, but yields a grave
To wretchedness.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.p: Hoy, of whence your ship, and whither are you bound?

sp.speaker: Davi.
sp.p:
We are of Marcelles, bound for Normandy.
Of whence are you?

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p: We are of the Sea.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: The Devil land you.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p: Bring your master aboard, or we will give you a broad side.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: As you are men I do conjure your valours.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
As you are virtuous keep from slavery.
A hapless, hapless maid.

sp.speaker: Davi.
sp.p:
Misdoubt it not fair maid,
There is not a man here, but well knows how much
He hath advantage of his enemy,
A race of thieves, Bankrupts, that have lain
Upon their countries stomach like a surfeit,
Whence being vomited they strive with poisonous breath
To infect the general air: Creatures that stand
So far from what is man, they know no good,
But in their prey, nor for necessity
But for mere hate to virtue, pursuing vice,
And being down themselves would have none rise.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
The curs are sure asleep, we will waken them,
Gunner give fire.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: In their own language answer them.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
Zounds do they begin to prate, have with you,
lace the netting, let down the fights, make ready the small
shot, gunner, give them a broad side, we will prate with them,
A star board there.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p:
Brave countrymen,
Think through how many dangers, with what sweat, what care,
How long expense of time, we have been getting
Those goods these Robbers fight for, that should make good to us
The sweet of just endeavours, look on this maid,
Think with what honourable welcomings,
You shall deliver her to her betrothed husband,
How much you shall engage him, lastly, think that you see,
Even all the miseries despised poverty
Can throw on men, that by this one hours valour
We only can redeem ourselves from death
O think how happy it is to innocence,
Where unto guilty souls it looks black and fearful:
At least let this all thoughts of fear dispel,
Truth fights gainst theft, and heaven opposes hell.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We are resolved Saint Dennis victory.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: A constant breast may fall, but cannot dye,

div2.stage: Enter Ward with a slaine friend, and Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Recall thy spirit brave friend, a while, yet stay,
At least bear thy revenge hence with thee.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: He hath lost all motion.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Injurious heaven that with so excellent matter
As is our soul, didst mingle this base mould,
So frail a substance earth, as if thou hadst framed man
The subject of thy laughter, gavest him a spirit
Free, unbounded, whose fiery temper breaks
Through all the clouds of danger, dares even heaven,
Swells and bears high, when with one little prick
This bubble breaks, displays a vanity,
Ridiculous vanity, this building
That hath been twenty and odd years a rearing,
One blast thus lays it flat, I could even tremble,
To think that such a coward I bear about me,
As is this flesh, that for so small a wound
Betrays our life.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
This shows sir, nature near intended man,
Other than as she sent him to the world,
All unoffensive, unarmed: when unto beasts,
She gave the means to hurt as to defence,
The armour she gave man was innocence.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p:
True, there was some other end in our creation
Then to be that which men term valiant.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: There was.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p: Courage brave sparks the slaves begin to faint,

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: It is his evil spirit sure that in this likeness haunts him

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: See where he lies.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.p:
'Sfoot we shall share the more sir, I always thought
Fortune had marked him out to dye by the French.
He had so much of the English spirit in him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Fortune! true, the fate of man is fixed,
Unmovable as the pole: how idle then were he
Should strive to cross unavoided destiny?
And think to stay his course, seeing we are swayed
As are the motionary engines of a clock,
By the dull weight that still doth downward tend,
Till it strike earth, and so there motion end.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Give me the hearing Sir,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Persuade no more, we have no will to act,
Or not to act more, than those orbs we see,
And planetary bodies, which in their offices
Observe the will of fate: the difference is,
They are confined, we are not: they are stars fixed,
We wandering Run on thou purple line
That drawest my life's fate out, thou that dost frown
Upon the births of men, now Saturne smile.
Those under milder Planets borne live, servile: good;
Mars called our Birth, my race shall be through blood

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
Abused knowledge that first werst given to man
A light, now helpest to dazzle him, and whatever want
Befall through our own imperfect judgment,
Unbridled will the throw on fortune, chance,
I see man's happiness, were his ignorance,

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.p: Aboard, aboard, aboard.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.p: Dear sir withdraw, you are deprived of sight

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p:
So much the better, I see no fear in fight,
Courage brave countrymen: what is natures part
May fall; what is heavens can never, it is the odds
That just men have of bad, still to the gods
They stand or fall.

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.p:
Enter, Enter, Enter.
Zounds the slave winks and fights.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
A Ward, A Ward, A Ward,
Down with them, down with them, away let him go overboard,
where he a second Alexander, there is not a man of them
lives, but shall go overboard, we will offer them to our deceased
friends in sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: My brother, my dear dear brother.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: There were no conscience, no religion in it,

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.p:
How? Conscience, were it but to banish those two
words they shall go overboard.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: They shall go overboard: suppose I speak the contrary.

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.p:
My Captain, my man of war speak the contrary
they are as safe as the great Turk.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Now they shall overboard.

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.p: Out-swaggered?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: How many French are left?

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
There is only five of four and twenty living.
Never did men with equal spirit stand,
A day so black and stormy: rob not yourself then,
Of so brave witnesses of this day's valour.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: How? dare you sir give us directions?

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p:
How dare I sir? I am a Gentleman
Equal unto yourself.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Take that now, I am before you,

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p: You are, I will not be long behind you.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Know, that our word shall be a law,

sp.speaker: Gallip.
sp.p:
That may be, for he hath had conscience by
the ears already.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Hoist me a vessel up of Maligo,
We will drink a health unto the wandering ghosts
Of our slain followers, and every draught
The Cannon makes report off, a French-man
Shall overboard, who to our friends may tell,
We drank a rouse to them,

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: As low as hell.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p:
Francisco Captain of the man of war, pursued our
prize, hath set a Pinnace forth, who according to the custom
of the sea, demands half of the spoil, to your demand he
threatens instant fight, force against force, or if you dare to
accept it, he makes you offer of single opposition.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Accept it? he could not name that honour
We covet more, reward the messenger,
They two shall be the hostages
For the equal trial, what is his weapon?
Where the place of fight?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p:
His weapons are sword and dagger, the place
Here on our hatches, both our ships being grappled,
The oath on each side given, who conquers the other
Shares the whole booty.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Agreed we seal to his condition,
Francisco call you him? I emulate
His daring spirit.

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.p: Fortune shapes our revenge you see.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
What need you give yourself unto this danger,
When in our general strength we have advantage?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
I prithee do not move my patience, I scorn to take
From others to my rising, he is only worthy state
From fortunes wheel plucks boldly his own fate,
And here is an arm shall do it.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: You see his insolence how he contemns us.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: No more, we are agreed.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: How shall we hinder their pursuit?

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.p:
When both the ships are grappled, privately
We will cut their hawsers, the wind blows fair
To give our lesser bark advantage, it is not ten leagues
To Tunis, where entered, we are as safe
As in a tower of brass.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: How if we shoot him, as we make away?

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.p:
By no means it shall be Franciscoes task
To cut his throat, this makes our revenge full,
We share the prise he fights for

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: Rare gull! we are all firm and secret,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: So that I rise, let the world sink, heaven fall.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
My merit: shall I thrall them? the sway of things,
Belongs to him dares most, such should be Kings,
And such am I, what nature in my birth
Denied me, fortune supplies: this maxim I hold,
He lives a slave, that lives to be controlled,
But see the man whose ruin crowns me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Art thou the chief and guider of this Bark?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: The same sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
May I impute it to your ignorance
In Marines actions, or the daring spirit,
That bars my right in thy achieved prise.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
This makes you answer, what do you see in me,
Doth promise I should be the sutler sir,
Fetch you provision in.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
A little calmer sir, you are not now in Kent,
Crying herrings seven a penny, nay we have heard of you;
You can bawl well, you have served a prenticeship
Unto the trade, affrighting of whole streets
With your full Oyster voice.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Poor fishers brat, that never didst aspire
Above a mussel boat, that wert not borne
Unto a fortune above two cades of sprats,
And those smoked in thy fathers bed-chamber;
That by a beggar in mere charity
Being made drunk, steed of a mariner
Wert stole aboard, and being awake didst smell
Worse than thy shell commodity at midsummer,
That desperate through fear wert made a Captain,
When to have been ashore again, thou wouldst have turned
Swabber unto a Peter-man.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
By all my hopes thou hadst been better digged
Thy grandsires Urn up and have swallowed it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thou barkest too much to bite.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Clear the deck there, each man bestow himself

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: It is done, there hauser is cut without descry,

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Away, farewell brave Captain, conquest sits on thy brow.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Leave me, I say

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Thou were never gulled till now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Give a charge there, say your prayers Knight, doom's
day is nigh

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
True it sinks thee to hell, whilst thus it bears me high.
Standest thou so long, thou hast some enchantment sure,
Or have I lost my wonted vigour?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Flatter no more thyself, wilt thou deliver
A moiety of thy prise up?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Yes, thus thou sharest it: Damnation! his sword falls.
O that my gall could spout out through mine eyes
A poisonous vapour to put out your lights,
And in a vale of darkness leave the world.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Wilt thou yet yield me right?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Know Francisco,
Wert thou an army that encompass me,
I would breath defiance to thee, and with this arm,
As shot from out a cannons mouth, thus would I make
A way through death and danger.

div2.stage: He flings away his sword, and aftær looseth his dagger.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
I do applaud thee, and that thou well mayst know
All valour is not confined within thy breast
I thus oppose thee, fortune shall have no share
In what I conquer.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Why, now I envy thee, thy life is mine,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Take it I dare thy let.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Not for the world, thus I return thy debt:
Not only in the prise but in myself
Thou hast an equal share, henceforth I vow the brother-hood.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your love, I ask no more.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
You need not, there is one gone before
Takes order for your share.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Whether makes the slaves, where is Gallop?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Posting as fast as his sails will bear him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Incarnate Devil forth-with give them chase,
Why movest not?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: They have cut our hausers we cannot budge a foot.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: The death of slaves pursue him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are too violent.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
To be baffled by a Cur, a foisting hound
My Zany: A creature without a soul
Made to mock man with.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Forbear I say, and let us turn our anger
On the next passenger.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Might I but live to see the dog-fish once again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Never doubt it sir, next prise we take forth-with
We will make to Tunis, mean time let revenge sleep
Those tides most violent are, which winds back keep,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
For this alone I vow, whom next I meet
Shall feel my fury, nation nor quality
Shall be their privilege, my sword now vengeance craves,
And who escape this do worse, I will sell for slaves.

div2.stage: Enter Dansiker, three or foure Sailers, Lief: Dansiker reads a letter.

sp.speaker: Leif.
sp.p: What news brave Captain?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
Good. These letters from my wife bring certainty
Of our obtained pardons, on condition
We henceforth for the state of France employ
Our lives and service.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Long live King Henry of France.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
My valiant friends this four years
Hath led you proudly through a sea of terror,
Through deeds so full of prowess they might have graced
The brow of worthiness, had justice to our cause
Given life and action. But since the breach of laws
Of Nations, civil society, justly entitles us
With the hateful style of robbers, let us redeem our honour
And not return into our country, with the names
Of pardoned thieves, but by some worthy deed,
Daring attempt, make good unto the world
Want of employment, not of virtue forced
Our former act of spoil and rapine.

sp.speaker: Leif.
sp.p:
Set the design down may regain us credit.
Deserve this grace so freely offered us
We will or accomplish it, or with our lives
Seal the attempt.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Brave Captain, through death we will follow thee,

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
Then thus, that with the same weapon, we may
Our country cure, with which we wounded her,
My purpose is to ruin all the Pirates
Lie in the harbour here.

sp.speaker: Leif.
sp.p:
Rare! it may be easy done, observe the wind
And firing but of one consume the rest.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
We must not trust to such uncertainties.
Thus I have plotted it: we first will set a fire
Some house in the town, to which when each man makes,
As they will be enforced from the haven
To yield their helps, with much facility
We may perform our purpose.

sp.speaker: Lif.
sp.p: How? undescried, shall we attempt the town?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
That charge be mine, the Renegado Jew,
You know gives free and open entertain
To all of our profession.in some out-house of his
I will convey a pot of wild-fire to it,
I will make a train of match, that at three hours
Shall give it fire.

sp.speaker: Sailers.
sp.p: Excellent! The time sir.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
Tomorrow night: mean time make ready
For our departure, but with such secrecy
Suspicion's self may not descry it: provide the balls
We must bestow upon the ships.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.p: That care be ours.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
The rest leave unto me,
We will return nobly, or else nobly dye.
Ruben, what news?

sp.speaker: Rub.
sp.p:
My master sir, desires your company,
There is a new Pirate landed, his name is Gallop.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
More yet? do they come on so fast?
Your master would engross his prize.

sp.speaker: Rub.
sp.p:
He would: and for your courtesy herein,
He will forbear three months the crowns you owe him:

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
I will use my Art sir to his benefit,
And for the Crowns, no longer I will delay him,
Here is my hand tomorrow night I will pay him.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
Speak freely, what think you of the new-come Captain,
Voada?

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p:
He looks as if his father and mother had got him in
fear: his eyes go like a City Catch-poles, several ways at
once, there is no stuff in him. Give me the Dutch Cavalier
Dansiker.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
Out upon him puff-paste, he was spoiled in his infancy,
ill-bred.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
How? spoiled with ill-bread? it was ill drink spoiled
him. I am of my master's mind, the new-come Pirate is a reasonable
handsome man of a Christian.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
Why? doth Religion move anything in the shapes
of men?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Altogether. What is the reason else that the Turk and
Jew is troubled (for the most part) with gouty legs, and
fiery nose, to express their heart-burning: whereas the Puritan
is a man of upright calf, and clean nostril.

sp.speaker: Uo.
sp.p:
Setting aside your nose, you should turn Christian,
then your calf swells upward mightily.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
How? I turn Christian? they have Jew enough already
amongst them: were it but three qualities they have, I will
be none of their society.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Three qualities? I prithee tell them us Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
First, they suffer their wives to be their masters. Secondly,
they make men thieves for want of maintenance, and
then hang them up for stealing. Lastly, they are mad four
times a year, and those they call Term-times, and then they
are so purged by their Physicians, which they name Lawyers,
some of them are never their own men after it. I turn Christian?
they shall have more charity amongst them first. They
will devour one-another as familiarly as Pikes do Gudgeons,
and with as much facility as Dutchmen do Flap dragons.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: How? eat up one-another?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Aye, eat up one-another: you have an innocent Christian
called a Gallant, your City Christian will feed upon no other
meat by his good will.

sp.speaker: Uo.
sp.p: But their wives will not feed on them too.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
The truth is, they are not altogether so great devourers;
marry they will be sucking at the bones. But see my master,
the great thief and the little thieves, the robbers and
the receiver.

div2.stage: Enter Iew, Gallop, Das. Sar. Sis.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
He is come. Thou powerful God of love, strike through mine eyes
Those awful darts of thine, whose burning heads
Pierce thorough hearts of ye, melt frostiest breasts,
Make all stoop to thy Deity. Now give thy art,
No God but Cupid pities mortal's smart.

div2.stage: Enter Dansiker, Benwash, Iew, Gismund, Fredericke, Carolo, Alizia.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.p: Five ducats a Tun, 'sheart the Cask is worth more,

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: You must remember at what rate you bought them.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.p: And at what price you may have more.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.p:
You speak like men that know how the market goes.
Your ear Jew.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
What misery remains to add to mine,
My brother lost his life in my defence;
And with his life, my sex and liberty,
I stand deprived of. Are not these wounds sufficient
To let out my weak breath? Thou flinty breast,
Art thou impenetrable? or is that thing called death
Too great a good for such a wretch as I am? It is, it is,
And that is the cause so many miseries
Do stop the way to it.

sp.speaker: Ièw.
sp.p:
I am your Merchant Ruben Rabshake, my wife, her sister
Fetch me three hundred Ducats for this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: This new-come thief sir?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Gentleman, slave.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Why your thief is a Gentleman, he scorns to do anything,
and he lives upon his comings in.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Peace dog, you see gallants, we are not Italianate to
lock our women up, we set them free, give open entertainment.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
It seems this Jew keeps a Bawdy-house, I like his wife
well, I could find in my heart to cast away half a Ducat
on her.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
You are of a noble mind sir, courtly and high ,
It is want of merit that breeds jealousy,
From which I know you clear.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
As I am from covetousness: how their eyes strike
each other? Rabshake -

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Captain, your gold.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
He saw our eyes meet, no matter, may I cool my heat
Let the world burn. Thy counsel Voada.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I do not like this fellow's looks, Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: He hath a hanging countenance indeed sir,

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Tush, my wife man, thou hast forgot how dear
I bought my liberty, renounced my law,
The Law of Moses, turned Turk, all to keep
My bed free from these Mahometan Dogs.
I would not be a monster Rabshake, a man-beast,
A Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
I have not forgotten sir that you damned yourself because
you would not be a Cornuto: If every man should fine
so dear for his horns, we should have but a few Christians
left: but seeing you fear your vessel hath a leak, wherefore
do you put her to sea, man her thus?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
For commodity: thou seest rich shop-keepers set their
wives at sale to draw in custom, utter their wares, yet keep
that I them untouched: all for profit man.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
I am not of your mind sir, there is no profit without
some pain.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
No more villain: should I suspect myself to have
that disease, I would run mad, first fury of my horns should
light on thee: look to it, thou art no longer living than my
wife is honest.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
I fear my days are but short then, if my life lasts
no longer than I can keep a Woman honest against her
will.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: It is a lovely boy, rare featured, would he were mine.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: It is so Uoada, he hath made the slave my Jailer.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: I have not seen so much of beauty in a man.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
You lose yourself. What man? what beauty? I tell
thee I am undone, Rabshake is made my over-seer.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p:
I would use him like an over-seer then, he should stand by
whilst the Executioner opened the bags: I must enjoy his
love, though quenching of my lust did burn the world besides.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: It is right Captain.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.p: Yes, it is right.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
But that is the wrong way sir, your followers expect
their equal shares.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
The fellow raves: talk to a Captain of equal sharing,
I will take order for landing the goods, and be with you presently.
Rabshake, thou knowest thy doom slave, look to it, thine
eyes, villain thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I will warrant you sir, I will look to it.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Here, carry them these two ducats to drink upon receipt
of the whole, I will deal like a commander with them, as
men do with their followers: that is, as you have followed
me to earn means, so now you shall follow me as long to
get your earnings, you shall be followers still, I will discharge
none of you.

sp.speaker: Sares.
sp.p:
We took him for a gull, but now I see he hath had
command, he can cheat his Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p:
I hope sir you will make better respect of your credit,
you know your oaths and promise.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
My promise, if a Citizen had bought a company, he
could but keep day with them: you must pardon him gentlemen,
a fresh Soldier wants seasoning.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: Salt us, look to it, we shall hardly relish you sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How? threatens and braves?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
Forbear, give the poor fellow leave to prate, he
pays for it.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p:
Good: you are now upon your guard, we shall meet
you upon discharge of the watch, and knock you down with
a bill of accounts, we shall skeld.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Out gull, talk to a commander, a man of war of equal
sharing, we have other use for our money than to pay followers.
Shall we accost these Ladies, gallants?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
It is the custom of the whole world, the greater thief
preys upon the less still: how is this?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: The happiness of the day befall you Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: The night equal the day's happiness, say I.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: All content both night and day stand to your desires.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Our desires equal your wishes sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Your desires are above my performance then.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
I am drawing on, if my life lie upon her honesty, I am
upon the point of giving up already.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: That Gentleman is very moving.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Could you not entreat him stay his pace.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: And trot in your ring, Lady, if you please.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
I purpose not to take a courser of your choosing, lest I
be jaded sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You presume the more of your own horsemanship.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Hoy-day, they are riding already, 'sfoot I am like to
go post to the Devil for this.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
Next night, time of my project, if I prove not as
hot a shot as came in your quarters since the loss of your
virginity, let me suffer the pains of Saint Anthonies purgatory.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
He must necessarily be a man of deeds, he is of so few
words.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You shall do well to put him to the trial.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
Without immodesty, may I question the reason you are
so heavy sir?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Nay then it rings out for me, should the Jew see this, I
were as good as speechless: there were but a little gasping
between me and the grave.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
The reason of my heaviness is, that you and I might
agree the better: for women love contraries, and you are
light I see.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
How is this? you see me light, true, to be in love
With one so far disdainful.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p: What success woman? the Dutchman and I have bartered wares.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
I have made exchange too, sold my liberty,
To purchase base ingratitude, I am rejected Voada.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: My Mistress, Gentlemen, did you see my Mistress?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Your business sirrah?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
You must make provision to entertain two of the richest
Pirates ever landed here, one Captain Ward and Franciscus,
they have brought a prize in worth three thousand ducats:
besides, they sell their prisoners slaves, my master hath
engrossed them all.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
Vengeance seize him and them. Back sirrah, say we
will expect them: you sir, attend your master his coming,
see you give us notice of it.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Nay, I hold it the best course too, for mine own safety.
My charge is charged my watch must be now, lest my Master
know it. If all the world were eyes, women I see would to it.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: I do but dream sure, Ward and Franciscus?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: What moves this passion?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Why look you pale?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Pale? I have a cause, I have less colour by six hundred Ducats
than I had.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: As how sir?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
I will tell you: I took an adventure to pay this Ward,
six hundred Ducats at our two meetings at Tunis, and see how the
Devil hath brought it about: I must leave you gallants.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: By no means: we will compound the business.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: I can conceal it no longer.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p:
You will betray yourself to their contempt, by your
own forwardness.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p:
I never shall have so fair occasion to speak my love
again, you know my husbands watchful jealousy.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p:
Now by my sex I am ashamed of you, were the Jew mine,
I would have no other Pander: be ruled by me
It is he shall hire the Captain to thy love,
And his own earning. What cannot we persuade?
"Man was asleep when woman's brain was made.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Thou givest me a new life, I am thy Scholar.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
I will prick thee forth a lesson, whose choicer strain,
Shall tell men that all Art against lust and women is vain.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
As you are men conceal your weapons, here are women
in the room.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: We are come to give you thanks for the two ducats sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: As you are of the sword, draw.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: We are fresh-men, we will powder you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Murder, murder, I shall be torn in pieces, by my hands.

div2.stage: Enter Ward, Franciscus, Ferd. Al. Page.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: Ward, Franciscus, we are betrayed, away.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
My noble general alive, come to my rescue, my
loyalty to the brave knight did thus engage me: the slaves
could not be content to stow me underboard, and force me
from thee, but would have shared the prize too: but I have
shared with them, see here is three hundred ducats, thou shalt
have them all brave spark, the Devil to boot with them.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p: Then you think this gold shall purchase your pardon.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
'Sfoot I am overjoyed with the sight of thee: see the
heroic Dansiker, his Captain Sare.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p: Your loves, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
This is no slave, he pays six hundred ducats at their meeting,
true, we are witness of it.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
I will be gulled for once thus, I will, these ducats
shall stop my mouth.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
'Sheart there are as many more in Bank, you shall have
them all, I prize thy countenance above a second Indies, were
they molten in your garbage. The world runs round with
me, Sicut erat in principio, naked I came in, and penniless I shall
go out.
What stays the Jew so long,

div2.stage: Enter Iew, Raymond, his two sonnes bound. Ruben.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
See he is come.
You will give my price sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: yes, for these slaves, I will.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p:
For ever be he servile that so makes them.
Hard-hearted; man, I cannot term thee, it is
A name that bears too much of pity in it,
Compared with so inhumane; creature wert thou a father,
These tears would move thee, that bemoan a sons,
Nay all my children's, worse than funeral,
Their ever thraldom, but nature well denied
Issue to thee, lest in thy barbarous guilt
She had been a party. When thy affectioned soul
Had felt how much the name of child moves, with what care,
How many jealous fears we view their infancy,
Lest having felt all this, thy accursed hand
Should yet have dared to make men childless.

sp.speaker: 1. Son.
sp.p: Can then your marble heart endure these drops?

sp.speaker: 2. Son.
sp.p:
The soil that bred you sir doth not bring forth
Such hideous monsters, that we should imagine
You can be so far cruel to betray
So many innocent lives, for in us bleed
An aged father, a mother, to whose grief
No other misery can be added.
Myself contracted to a virtuous maid,
Who ere this hath left Marcel,
And in Normandy expects the consummation of our happiness.
You have our goods, our ship, all the substance
Should succour our old parents, you have only left
These arms to earn them bread, and can your eyes
Relentless see these chained?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Do not they move you sir?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Yes, as the Jew, art not thou moved Benwash?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
As a hangman at an execution makes no other holiday
in the year.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Inhuman dog! O I could tear thee villain,

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
I will give thirty crowns for this old beast to be revenged
on him.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p:
Be gentle, take his money, forgive me sir,
I see you are kind, would not now part us
That twenty and odd years have grown together,
Will you not take it? give him so Jew,
I will deserve them, see I am not old,
No wrinkle is on my brow, these are but frowns,
Raised by his unkind refusal of my offer.
See what plump veins I have, no sinews shrunk,
These are not gray-hairs, they are only white
To show the lightness of my spirit: come
Manacle these arms, you shall see us three
Tug the day's eye out, there is not a father
And his two boys shall dare to undertake us,
The sun out-vied we will set us down together
And with our sadder cheer out-mourn the night,
And speak the happiness we might have lived too:
How by mine own hearth in cold winter-eves
I might have told my sons some ancient tales,
Which they might one day from their grandsire speak.
We will add unto our woes thus by compare
Of what our joys might have been, then we will curse,
And when we want a plague, we will think upon
This bloody murtherer, we shall have store then:
Be eloquent in bitter execrations,
Our choler vented, then again we will weep,
Till tears glue up our eyes to mock sad sleep.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1. Son.
sp.p:
Dost laugh at aged sorrow? be just ye powers,
As ye judge innocents causes, revenge ours.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: My money for them Jew, so, away with them.

sp.speaker: Alb., Ferd.
sp.p: We will redeem them, pay their ransom,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: You redeem them? your means?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: All that we have aboard,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Such another syllable, I will make a sale of you too.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I am your first man, I will give you 400 crowns for them

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: A sale of us?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
Know that if all our fortunes will set them free, it is
theirs.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: I will try that, give me 400 crowns.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: They are yours, I will justify the sale,

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Of your own fellows, countrymen do they not stand
Conditioned as yourself.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Who gave you patent to examine him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Forbear, because you are men of action I will descend
To give you notice they are my lawful prize,
Such as denied my party, would willingly
Betray me, yea all of us, into the hands
Of our vowed enemies.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Are you not men of war then?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
We are no Pirates sir, our country yield us
More honest means of living.

sp.speaker: Sar., Om.
sp.p:
Away with; them more honest means of living
make them sure,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Give us the hearing.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Away with them. Zounds I will set them free else.

sp.speaker: 2. Son.
sp.p: Let us take our fathers blessing with us yet.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: All curses under heaven go with you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p:
Is there no ear for misery to beat at?
My sons, Fredericke, Albert, they are gone, sent
To perpetual vassalage, I loved you boys
A little better than to outlive your slaveries.
I will not curse thee monster, I know my thoughts
Cannot arrive unto so black revenge,
As shall attend thee: crack, crack, you overladen strings,
And set a miserable old man free,
So, so, I will appeal for you my sons to yon high Court
Here none but beasts of prey Tigers resort.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: I hate this villain, he is all blood.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
My heart I think would break
But that in steed of words, mine eyes thus speak.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
How is it my noble spirits dulled with one Tragedy,
Let us digest it with a gig, a catch.
Come wine there, shall we to hazard?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
I willingly would stake my life to thine at that just
game, there wants but an occasion.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: What is your sport?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Adams game at one whole, every male to his female

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: How should we be furnished?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I will fit you with an Eve sir, a temptress,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: What is she?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
Your peer, a beauty that would take you
From out yourself to gaze at her,
The Jew's wife's sister.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: First sight of her yields thee a 100 Ducats.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
I will be a conjunction copulative to join you together
for the money, it is a fate follows us soldiers when we are
down: the reason is, we hold it no shame to live upon spoil
of the enemy, and a greater foe to man than a whore is impossible,
'Sheart I am prevented, the Jew panders them himself,
that is she sir, that Turk is her brother, his name is Crosman.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: The slave hath a goat in his looks.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: That is he in the Judas beard, use but thy art he is thine.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
If I liked not his thirty thousand Ducats, better than his
person, I would never strain my complexion for him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
She equals thy commends indeed, so true a fair
I never beheld till now.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
Nay more to entice me, this well stuffed purse
He did enforce upon me, but it is your sin,
So you have profit, all religious laws
Must suffer violence, your wife be exposed
Unto all undergoers.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Forgiveness honest wife, my chaste, chaste, wife.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
Nay, use your pleasure, you had best keep the gold
To guild your shame with, I trow I would give it him,
Tell him he must not think I am the woman
He takes me for, if he will not believe you,
Let him make trial with the ladder of ropes
He vowed to clime my chamber with, this night,
When, as it seems, he learnt you were enforced
To be in the Synagogue.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Better and better, I cannot but admire thy chastity
A ladder of ropes, would he make that the beginning
Lechery should be the end of, I will hamper him,
If he have any grace thy honesty overthrows him,

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: If he have any wit it will I hope.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
My dull eyed villain Rabshake saw none of this, He is
all for rem in re, he would have me a cuckold by law forsooth,
by statute law, I shall put you a book case, for he shall moot I will
prize him but to the present business. Noble Captain to express
how much you are welcome, my wife and sister, laying
all rites aside, and customary observes, come to invite you to
a mean banquet sir.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Best thanks sir, your welcomes prodigal,
I am already feasted in this bounteous dish sir.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
But you are not likely to surfeit on it, I will have a finger
in the platter, with you, were you the great Turks self.

div2.stage: Sar. Dans. against Francisco, Gal. & Cros. parts them, Iew hides himselfe.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
With me, I tell thee Dansiker
Thou dost not merit with thy lips to touch
So choice a rarity, what darest thou for her?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: What thou darest not.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: I will put that to the trial,

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p: As you come of women.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
By, all the rites you owe our sex, as you are men enforce
them part.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Respect the place, you are in danger of law.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: You shall oversway me Lady, we shall meet again sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: So you are men

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Are they gone?
What hard fortune attends me? that none of their throats were
cut, I might have seized their goods, not so much as the flesh
bitter, but is come of.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
'Sheart, this poverty makes a man valiant, when I had
my ducats I had no more heart than a Jew.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: And that was the reason your so willingly parted with them sir

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
Old Benwash, where hidest thou thy head in this day
of battle man?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Here under this table, did you think I am so branch
No roof would give me covering, I am but a pricket,
A mere sorrel, my head is not hardened yet
Though thanks unto your mastership your fire was not wanting

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: You speak in Hebrew I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Yet you can speak the whoremasters language passing
well; what made you sir take my wife for a flesh-seller, a whore?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: You are abused sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
By thee lecher, you know not this purse, this gold?
You have your tricks to climb up cuckolds haven,
Your ladder of ropes, you had best keep that hour,
My wife this night expects you: my absence
Will be enforced, she bid me tell you so,
Insatiate goat thou thinkst our wives are such,
As are your holy sisters, religious Votaries,
Your spittle nuns, here take your ill got trash,
May I but know thou once more temptest my wife,
You shall not need a ladder, I will mount you sir
I will, you ox-gall, I will.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Ha, this is gold.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Do you hear sir, hereafter know a Turks wife from a Christians
You are one of those hold all women bound
Under the domination of the Moon;
All wavering, now you have seen one of the Sun sir,
Constant you slave, and as she is, with us are millions more.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Benwash, brother, 'Sfoot I have sought each nook
of the house for you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: It is beyond my thoughts, imaginations drowned in it.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Rare, doth she plead chastity?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Like a bawd that would put off a virginity, the knight
is as good as ours already, besides I have procured the Governor
in person to regreet him
All that art can by ambition, lust, or flattery do,
Assure yourself this brain shall work him to.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Nay if the flesh take hold of him, he is past redemption
He is half a Turk already, it is as good as done
Woman is hell out, in we never return.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Were not I confident of my good parts, this gold
would buy me out of my five senses, a full purse, a ladder of
ropes, and his wife in the tail on it able to overcome any man
breathing, yet what should I fear that have so many good
Angels about me? sure she is in love with me, it is no other,
and out of her honesty it seems she hath vowed to do nothing,
but what she dares acquaint her husband with, if she
have made him usher his own crest I will swear she is a woman
of the Sun, she hath dazzled his eyes well, this night
makes the trial, I will take your instructions Jew, climb the
matter of preferment.
It may be it was my destiny gave me this crown,
Women and ropes should raise me, that put others down.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
I am ore charged sir with so high a favour
As your descending thus to visit me.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p:
You are the man we covet, whose valour
Hath spake you, so impartial worthy,
We should do wrong to merit, not gracing you.
Believe me sir, you have injured much yourself,
Vouchsafing familiarity with those
Men of so common rank as Dansiker,
Your hopes should fly a pitch above them,

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
It may be that our clime stands not to give
That full content, the air you drew at home,
And therefore purpose shortly a return.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
I know no country I can call home
What by your courtesy I might, my desert stands
Not to make promise of.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p:
Detract not from yourself, call this your own
I see there speaks a fortune in your brow
Will make us proud to have acknowledged you.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
I will gage a thousand Ducats on equal terms,
I live to see him the Sultans Admiral.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Why not as well as the great Customer,
My allied kinsman Governor, neither borne Turks,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
I dare not look so high, yet were I employed,
What a poor Christian could, I durst make promise of.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Christian or Turk you are more wise I know
Than with religion to confine your hopes.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p:
He is too well read in Poesy to be tied
In the slave's fetters of religion.
What difference in me as I am a Turk,
And was a Christian? life, liberty,
Wealth, honour, they are common unto all?
If any odds be, it is on Mahomets side,
His servitors thrive best I am sure.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Is this the hook your golden bait doth cover?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
I have oft with laughter thought how innocent
My thoughts when first I turned were, how scrupulous
I was, when with one argument I was confirmed; as thus,
If this religion were so damnable
As others make it, that God which owes the right
Profaned by this would soon destroy it quite.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p:
That is easily answered, heaven is merciful,
By their destruction it should take all means
From giving possibility to their change,
And so unjustly damn them, but for my part,
It is not Divinity but nature moves me,
Which doth in beasts force them to keep their kind.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
But men that have two ends, safety and profit,
Where beasts no farther are transported
Than with the present object, must make their actions
Turn to those points.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p: Both which are in some sort proposed to you.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p:
As thus, for profit, you cannot with yourself
Imagine, that your virtue can be smothered,
Might there but be assurance of your trust.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: How should I give you that?

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p: As we did; turn Turk.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
That were the way to more uncertainty,
Men sooner open foes than fained friends try
And where men's acts from their own ends proceed,
More look unto those ends than like the deed,

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: This gudgeon will not bite.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p:
But when there are examples plentiful,
To instance against your words, you need not fear,
Men what they see oppose against what they hear.

sp.speaker: VVar.
sp.p:
The cunning fowler to beguile the birds
Brings up some tame, and lets them fly abroad
To draw in others, that their liberty
May be the bait to others misery.
Such is state-policies, sometime a to advance an ill,
When others for less crimes it oft doth kill.
But to cut off your further argument
What is mine of prowess, or art, shall rest by you
To be disposed of: but to abjure
My name, and the belief my ancestors
Left to my being. I do not love so well
The earth that bore me, to lessen my contempt
And hatred to her, by so much advantage,
So oblique act as this should give to her.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Work in my sister presently.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
You are yourself free, nor will I further
Dissuade your resolution, nor less esteem
Your merit, and fair worth.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p: You engage me to you sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
He enjoys too much by promise to be won,
It must be a woman's act, to whom there is naught
That is impossible: What Devils dare not move
Men to accomplish, women work them to.
And see, in happy time she is come, we will single them.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Here comes an argument that would persuade
A God turn mortal, until I saw her face,
I never knew what men term beauty was:
Besides whose fair, she hath a mind so chaste
A man may sooner melt the Alps than her.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: We will along with you, when makes she hence?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
The wind sits fair, the slaves are sending down
Whom the next morn bears hence.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
We will aboard with you fair sir, we will leave
Our love exchanged with you, some happier time
May perfect that good work I wish were mine.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
My truest services: nay Lady stay
Though hitherto I have been a hapless Orator,
Your milder measure, or my love-taught tongue,
May find more fortunate hours: for by that guide,
Which rules and knows our thoughts -

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p:
Reserve your oaths sir to more easy ears,
I understand myself too well to credit them.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Un-gentle maid to triumph in my torment,
If ever breast did feel the power of love,
Or beauty made a conquest of poor man
I am thy captive, by heaven, by my religion.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p:
As my belief is in that, my faith gives trust
To your protests.

sp.speaker: VVar.
sp.p: Then by thy God, by the great Mahomet.

sp.speaker: Uo.
sp.p: Too weak a bond to tie a Christian in.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
What shall I swear by? propose an oath to me
The breach where of would at once sink me lower
Than hell knows being, I will take it willingly.

sp.speaker: Uo.
sp.p:
I will be concealed no longer, know then I love,
But not the man whose daily Orisons
Invoke confusion on me, whose religion
Speaks me an Infidel.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
'Sheart I am of none, only to feed discourse,
And fill up argument.

sp.speaker: Uo.
sp.p:
But you must be of one if you will enjoy me,
If then your thoughts answer to what you speak
Turn Turk I am yours.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Turn Turk?

sp.speaker: Uo.
sp.p:
Do you demur already? how prodigal your words
Spoke your affection, and with one simple trial
Are you struck mute.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: With patience hear me Lady.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p:
False knight, I have given too calm an ear already
To thy enchanted notes.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p: Should I for ever sell my liberty?

sp.speaker: Uo.
sp.p:
You need not, it is sufficient glory
You have betrayed a maidens liberty.
But I will do penance for my so black a sin,
Doting on thee, I will henceforth hate thy whole sex:
The name of man to me, shall as the rock
From which the shipwrecked wretch hath lately scaped
Bring fear in the name of it: keep off false Siren.
Heaven well ordained man should the woman woe,
Should we their hard-hearts prove, we all ill should know.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p: Stay, I will enforce thee else.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
Do these my tears delight thee then? cruel
Hard-hearted man, glut thy relentless sight
With full-eyed sorrow.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
She is all amorous, all fair, that she doth love,
Behold those tears whose drops would pierce the hearts
Of Tigers, make them pitiful,
They are witnesses she feigns not: leave, leave to weep,
Lest putting out those lights the world should mourn.
Put on a veil of black, I am thine own.
If there be any Divinity, it hath
His seat in beauty: thou art a God to me
My Country, friends, nay, being, what wouldst thou have.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p: To be no other than myself I crave.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
I am no more mine own, rather than lose
So true a happiness, as thy constant love,
There is no way so black I would not prove,
That lies from heaven to hell. Crosman in vain
Thy arguments were spent wouldst thou prevail?
Here is an Orator can turn me easily,
Where beauty pleads, there needs no sophistry.
Thou hast ore-come me Voada.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p:
And I will raise thee but thou dost name a good,
I cannot call mine till I am possessed of it.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Call in thy friends, make preparation,
I will take the orders instantly,
My speed shall give prevention to the prate
Of the idle multitude: away, the flame doth burn
Which sets the world on fire, and makes me turn.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
Thou art all harmony, best love I fly,
I have my ends,
However thou sink, thy wealth shall bear me high.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
So, the day leaves the world, chaste Uoada
Nothing can make him miserable enjoys thee:
What is it I lose by this my change? my Country,
Already it is to me impossible,
My name is scandaled? what is one Island
Compared to the Eastern Monarchy? this large
Unbounded station shall speak my future fame;
Besides, they are slaves stand subject unto shame.
One good I enjoy, outweighs all ills what ever
Can be objected; to sum my happiness:
That God on earth, to whom all men stand bare,
(Gold) that doth usher greatness, lackeys me,
I have more than I can spend, what wants
Is in command, and that my valour makes
Due purchase of, I will rather lead on slaves
Than be commanded by the power of Kings.
Beauty, Command, and Riches, they are these three
The world pursues, and these do follow me.
Speak, what news Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
The tongues of ravens are too mild to speak it,
The very thought where of methinks should turn
Your hair to quills of Porcupines, it is the denial
Of your Redeemer. Religion, Country,
Of him that gave you being.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
The slavery of man, how this religion rides us!
Deprives us of our freedom from our Cradles,
Ties us in superstitious bondage.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Heaven stop mine ears from hearing thy dishonour.
Upon my knees I do conjure you sir,
Sell not your soul for such a vanity,
As that which you term Beauty, eye-pleasing Idol,
Should you with the renouncing of your God
Taking the abhorred name of Turk upon you,
Purchase a little shameful being here, your case
Might be compared to his, who adjudged to death
By his heads loss, should crave (stead of one stroke)
To dye a lingering torment on the rack.
Even such would be your life, whose guilt each hour
Would strike your conscious soul with terrors.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: No more, this boys words trouble me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
If none of these move, let the example
Of that contempt is thrown on runagates
Even by these Turks themselves, at least move you
To fly this slavery.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Most worthy sir, now I dare call you brother,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Too fair a name to cloak so great a foe,
This instant makes a trial of your virtue,
Think on Ulysses constancy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why are you mute sir?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: I am not well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas! how can he, being so near to hell?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Are you so weak to have a boys words sway you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You have not mine, think it is heavens hand doth stay you

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Have you no other but my sister sir,
To make a stale of, did you not vow?

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Whatever, I do recant it, I am now
Myself, her looks enchanted me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Against a man's own soul, no oath can tie.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: This thy disgrace revenged shall speak in blood.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: Where is my betrothed husband? All is ready.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
To publish infamy to thee and us?
The weathercock is turned, this boys breath did it.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p: Again turned?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
You cast your eyes too much upon the flame
Proves your destruction.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p:
Un-gentle boy, dost thou requite me thus?
How canst thou blushless view me, have my tears
Procured me naught but scorn?

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Forgiveness Uoada: turn back thy comet-eyes,
Plagues, Devils, poverty, may all ills fall
Man ever was subject to, I will enjoy thee.
Force hence, I say, this boy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
As I from hence, so thou art thrust from joy, eternal
joys.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
The Mufty is here: you know the custom sir,
Some trivial ceremonies, they will be soon over,
They once performed you are never unhappy more.
Besides, the Captainship of our strong Castle
Shall be my sisters portion, here is the key.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Do not delay them then.

div2.stage: Enter the Slaues bound, going to the Port.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: They are come sir.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
What mean these slaves, their sights like Basilisks
Foretells my ruin: 'sheart make this way.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
Nay, do not shun our sight, hear us but now,
We will forgive all our wrongs, with patience row
At the unwieldy oar: we will forget
That we were sold by you, and think we set
Our bodies against your soul, the dearest purchase
Of your Redeemer, that we regained you so,
Leave but this path damnation guides you to.

sp.speaker: 2. Son.
sp.p:
Our blood, our Fathers blood, all is forgiven,
The bond of all thy sins is cancelled,
Keep but thyself from this.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p:
Let us redeem our countries shame by thee,
We willing will endure our slavery.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: The words do rip my heart up: ha?

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p:
Why stand you in this dilemma: are you deprived
Of sense and being?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Thou tellest me true: with what brain can I think
Heaven would be glad of such a friend as I am.
A Pirate, murderer? let those can hope a pardon care
To atone with heaven, I cannot, I despair.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you yet hear me? yet heaven hath mercy.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
And hell damnation: on, zounds on I say,
The way that leads to love is no black way.

div2.stage: The dumbe shew, with Chorus of Ward turning Turke.

Enter two bearing halfe-moones, one with a Mahomets head following. After them the Muffty, or chiefe Priest: two meaner Priest bearing his traine. The Muffty seated, a confused noyse of musicke, with a showt. Enter two Turkes, one bearing a Turban with a halfe-moone in it, the other a robe, a sword: a third with a Globe in one hand, an Arrow in the other: two Knights follow. After them Ward on an Asse, in his Christian habite, bare-headed. The two Knights, with a low reuerence, ascend, whisper the Muffty in the eare, draw their swords, and pull him off the Asse. He layd on his belly, the Tables (by two inferiour Priests) offered him, he lifts his hand vp, subscribes, is brought to his seate by the Muffty, who put on his Turban and Roab, girds his sword: then sweares him on the Mahomets head, vngirts his sword, offers him a cuppe of wine by the hands of a Christian: Hee spurnes at him, and throwes away the Cuppe, is mounted on the Asse, who is richly clad, and with a showt. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
But thou wilt find it black: no hell I see is so low
Which lust and woman cannot lead us to.

Here could I wish our period, or that our Pen
Might speak the fictions, not the acts of Men.
The deeds we have presented hitherto, are white
Compared unto those black ones we must write:
For now no more at men, but Giant-like
The face of heaven itself, he dares to strike:
And with a blushless front he dares to do,
What we are dumb to think, much more to show:
Yet what may fall beyond uncertain guess
Your better favours bind: us to express.

The accursed Priests of Mahomet being set;
Two Knights present the wretch, who finds no let
To his perdition: to whom nor shame, nor fear
Give any curse. Dismounted from that steed
Did best befit the rider: they then read
The Laws of their damned Prophet: he subscribes,
Enrols his name into their Pagan Tribes.
Now wears the habit of a free-borne Turk,
His sword excepted, which lest they should work
Just villainy to their seducers, is denied
Unto all Runagates, unless employed
In wars against Christians. Last, O be he last
Forswears his name! with what we blush to tell,
But it is no wonder, blacks the way to hell,
Who though he seem yet happy, his success
Shows he exchanged with it, and wretchedness.
Give patience to our Scene, which hereto tends,
To show the world, black deeds will have black ends.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: Ward turned Turk? it is not possible.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
I saw him Turk to the Circumcision.
Marry therein I heard he played the Jew with them,
Made them come to the cutting off an Apes tail.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
I see the hand of heaven prevented mine,
Death was too fair a guerdon for him. But to the present,
Deserving sir, I now am to conjure you
By all the offices of friendship past,
By what my future love, and means may stead you,
To vow performance of one small request.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Whatever it be I will be as just to you
As heaven to truth: by all that Ward denied,
I vow me yours.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
I accept your faith: know then that I am bound
Unto a desperate attempt, how it may succeed,
Heaven and Fate only know. The circumstance
I do enjoin you further not to enquire.
What on your trust is imposed is the redeeming
Those two betrayed young men, whom Ward did sell,
When to his barbarous cruelty they opposed,
And lost themselves, and state: their ransom is here,
As you prove just, from all mishaps rest clear,

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
And if I fail to accomplish your desires,
All my sins haunt me, when my breath expires.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
I am most confident, best sir adieu,
If Dansiker do live, he lives to you.
Hast laid the train to my directions?

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p:
It is done to the undoing of them all,
Time calls aboard which spends not half an hour
Before our train do take it rests to be determined
What ships we fire, which bear along with us.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
Danvils makes with us, all the rest give fire to,
Sares ship except, to him we are engaged,
Nor will we prove ungrateful, are all things ready,

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p: To your own wishes.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
Aboard then instantly, Tunis fare-well,
Dansiker bids all pirates now adieu.
He will show you, what you might do, were you true

div2.stage: Enter Agar aboue in the window

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
How dull a pace keeps time to lovers eyes,
And yet to me how swift the nights black horse,
Makes way to raise the morn, whose least of light
Takes all my hopes from me and damps me quite,
Eleven and yet not come, he was not capable
Of my quaint stratagem, or being possessed
Of what he wanted, gold, contemns my love,
It is no other Agar, he loathes thee,
Man's curse is, things forbid, still to pursue
What is freely offered not to hold worth their view,
Ha? unless my credulous ears deceive me,
There one make towards my window,

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
The coast is clear. Bawd night I do salute thee
Thou that dost wink at all faults, that huggest so many sins in
thy black bosom, the Sun grows pale to view them, to
thee damnations nurse I make my prayer, conjure thee by all
my lustful embraces thou hast been witness to, by all the cuckolds
thou hast made betwixt morn and twilight to add one
to the number, but one thou black eyed negro, never did
woman make such shift to dub her husband, though many
thou dost know have made most bare ones, O let this instrument
that hath so many freed from the hell of Usurers, and
from the jaws of their fear, bandogs, hath paid so many's
debts relieve my wants, I will never blame thee, fortune henceforth
if I lack, put thyself but this once on my my back,
no false light in the window, no bawdy land-mark no handkerchief
to waft me, I will venture it, Agar, my lovely Agar.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
It is he who in this dead of night calls on my
name.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Thy friend, thy understanding friend, with the ladder
of ropes, here make them sure above, leave meto the lower parts.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: I hope you mean no wrong sir to me.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
I will do thee as much right as can be done to one of
thy sex, hast made it fast?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: You may adventure sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
He that will not adventure for such a piece of flesh,
were worthy to feed upon dumplings all days of his life, nay I
will venture, thou warden of the horned livery, omnipotent
Uulcan, now set my shafts but right,
I will make one freeman more ere it be light.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p:
There is no remedy, that which makes
waiting women punks, and Captain's panders, that causeth decayed
Gentlemen become solicitors, and bankrupt Citizens Sergeants,
that makes us thieves, necessity, that which hath no
law on his side.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: We shall have as little conscience anon in robbery.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p:
Aye, should we rob hospitals, our betters have made
that a monopoly, but to steal from a rich Jew it is no more sin
than to unload a weary Ass.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: By hook or crook you will have it.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p:
We were bred in a country that had the charity to
whip begging out of us, when we were young, and for starving,
manhood denies it, you know what must necessarily follow.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: Nay make your conclusion.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p:
Press her in a dumb show, hereabouts should be
the house, great windows and a little wicket, noble man-like,
what is here a ladder of ropes, 'Sfoot we are prevented,
Saint Nicolas Clerks are stepped up before us.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p:
Were they ten justices' Clerks we would share
with them.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p:
Their Masters would prevent us for that, yet
since our case is desperate, we will put in with them.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: Softly for waking the maids.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p:
'Sheart, thou art the son of a lapland-witch sure,
this is the maids chamber, one of them is in a dream, she fetcheth
her wind short I am sure.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: How long thou art poking at it, what is it man?

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p: Some light commodity or other.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p:
A woman's lower part, it is altogether in fashion for
them to be light about the bum indeed.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p:
I have the male part to it, the doublet, your women
will have it ever in request to have the man's part uppermost.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p:
'Sheart, a French slop, these are none of the Jew's
trousers, and they should be no gallants, for he hath money in
his purse.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p:
Aye marry sir, this fellow had good ware about him
indeed, upon my life we are little better than bawds, get money
by others Venery, this Jew is a

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: Water, water, water

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Fire, fire, fire, the slaves lie on straw-beds, and yet this
cry will take no hold on them, fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
Flames and brimstone, I am in hell, Zounds my breathes,
the ladder, this Jew hath found us out and fired the house.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Dear sir contain yourself.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
A plague on venery, a hot end comes on it still, is the
window high enough that I may break my neck, dye any
death rather than be roasted?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
Here is a vault leads to the common shower, it being
low-water the sheets shall let you down to your escape.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Those sheets have brought me low enough already.
Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Flames stop thy throat.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Dear sir adventure it and save your life.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
Were it to hell I must,
A plague on whores say, whose vast desires
Begins in watery tears and end in fires.

div2.stage: Enter Rabshake at one dore, and Iew at another.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: An Ocean overwhelm thee, where is the fire slave?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: At the Jew's house, Benwash his house, your house sir:

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
My bags, my obligations, my wife Agar I say, I shall
run mad, I will scale the windows, burn for company, my
money and myself will go together, what is here a ladder
of ropes, Gallops breeches, burn on, burn on, singe all the
world, consume it with thy flames, thou best of elements,
burn on I say.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: As you are men on this side help to save our goods.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
As you are ministers of Lucifer let it burn on, it is
mine own house, come but on my ground I will have my action
for it.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: He is distracted, help as you are men.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Dogs, villains, thieves, down with him that lays a
hand a to it, be just you powers of heaven, and throw thy wild
fire down upon the heads of these adulterers, room, room,
room, I have it, I have it, room, room, room.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
The Jew is mad indeed, his loss distracts him, speak
gentle friend, doth the fire slack.

sp.speaker: Rub.
sp.p:
The house is saved, but all the ships in the harbour
Unquenchable do burn.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: The ships in the harbour.

sp.speaker: Rub.
sp.p: Yours only excepted.

sp.speaker: Frans.
sp.p: My thoughts now have their ends,

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
Do not thou grieve boy, know I love thee
Thy maintenance shall express it, I have friends
And jewels left for thee, but I hate thee more
Than all thy wealth made me love thee before.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
False woman, thou shalt not shake me off thus
Were all the impudence of thy whole sex,
All their blushless impieties confined in thee
I will move thy flinty heart to sense and shame,
I will thou sorceress: now I do see too late
There is a hand ore-rules our will and fate.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
This shows the greatest plague heaven keeps in store
Falls, when a man is linked unto a whore.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
I have it, I have it, here, here, nay come on, you have
come off I am sure, here is evidence looks pale to think but
on it, you do not know the tenant to this cottage, he was an
upright dealer, he paid meto a hair, come forward and be
hanged, I shall advance you in a ropes name, you have made
no cuckold of me. I made myself one, pondered any own
horns, now sirrah, you that go to it by art, put your cases one
in the neck of another, you rem in re what think you of
this case.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
I think the serpent crept into a narrow hole, and left
his case behind him.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Then I am a Cornuto.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: This makes the naked truth appear so.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: The best is, the crest is mine own, I paid well for it.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Dear husband pardon me, I will confess,

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
What wilt thou confess? that thou hast made a mere
Ass of me, to pay thy journeyman wages before hand.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
It should seem he laboured hard to earn it, he could
keep no clothes about him.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
This slave doth not think I will cut his throat for this,
you have watched nearly sirrah, you have.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Unless I should have been their bawd, I could watch
no nearer, methinks she hath done you a great pleasure, rid
you of your disease, jealousy, now you need fear no more,
you are in possession of it, your doubts are at an end.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Good, very good, my doubts are at end, but I shall
hang you in suspense for this: you Manticora that plump
upon raw flesh, here set your hand to this letter, that I may
draw your Captain on again upon the breach, I will blow you
up else, why move you not, I am sure you laid your hand to
the business when time was.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
Pardon me sir, I know my life is forfeit
To your just anger, nor will I be the means
To shed more blood, mine shall suffice alone,
Since only one is wronged punish but one.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
She loves him still, I am a cuckold
He has out-gon me, do you hear; subscribe
Move me no further.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: The worst can be but death, I will not.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
I tell thee I will forgive thee, give my revenge
Scope but at him, thou art free.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Swear it by Abrahams dust, the ashes of our fore-fathers.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Dust and ashes it is but a frail oath.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
By that, and all that ties a virtuous mind,
I vow and swear by written writ.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: You will swear as much to forgive me I hope too sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Why, thou shalt be the messenger, nay the actor
In my just vengeance.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: The hang-man you mean sir, I am expert at it.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Francisco, what news man?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The worst your ears can hear, our ships

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: They are untouched, of all they are only safe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
You dazzle your own eyes, that villain Dansiker
Hath grappled them and fled.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Whirlwinds pursue him, heaven, seas, earth, all at once
Join to his confusion, now I do see too late
There is a hand ore-rules our will and fate.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
I shall then take your promise, your brother being
redeemed, this night I shall enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: This Diamond binds me to it, by this I swear.
