sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
It is thine I will bestow it on thee, to tie thy faith
Thou hast his ransom.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: It is here.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p:
About it then, now fortune equal prove
I am happy, yet her lust redeems my love.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Yet see, midst all my miseries I have a friend,
My constant loyal Voada, could what we enjoy
Make a man happy, I am not miserable.
Thou comest to comfort me, I know thou dost.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p: This fellow raves sure: do you know to whom you speak?

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Put not a further trial on me, thou best of women:
Know if this arm were barred all other means
From hearts of Christians, it should dig thee food.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
We know you are a bloody murderer, and are repaid
By our just Prophet, that hates false Runagates.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
How couldst thou malice man so much, heaven,
As to create a woman?
Thou hast forgot me sure: O look on him
That hath denied his faith, sold all his hopes
to purchase thee his bride.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
To match with beggary: know I contemn thee
As a most abject slave, and hate thee more
Than all thy wealth could make me love before.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.p:
What mean you sir? could you expect a good,
A happiness from hell? she is a whore.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Thou liest: this arm shall make it good,
My soul for her I lost, and now my blood.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Your passion doth transport you, here comes her pander,
One that knows all her secrets: examine him,
If she stand clear, let my life answer it.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p: I will put you to the Test.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
I have had a hot night of this, nothing but fire in my
mouth two hours together: marry the old Jew my master I
hear hath stumbled on a cooler. I thought this Captain
would be coming so long on upon the breach he would
break his neck at the last. This venery is a tempting dish,
some never lin licking at it till they burn their lips. Well, I
must go comfort up old Benwash, he is heavy upon his wife's
lightness.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p: You Jew, a word with you?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
You Turk, I have nothing to say to you: Ha, ha, ha,
poor fellow, how he looks since Mahomet had the handling
of him? he hath had a sore night at Who is that knocks at
the backdoor? Cry you mercy, I thought you were an Italian
Captain.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Zounds, leave your circumlocutions, I will send your
head to your heels else.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
You parcel bawd, all usher, answer directly who it is
bears away the prize in your Mistresses race, or I will spoil
your footing, cut you off by the hams.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Alas sir!

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Speak, who are her suitors?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Uoada's suitors? O sir, a Barbar sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
I will make you have need of a Surgeon ere I have done
with you. How do you know he is a Barber?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
He smells strong of Rose-water, and he hath never money
in his purse but on Saturday-nights.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: What other suitor, slave?

sp.speaker: Rab.
Fran.
sp.p:
This dog deludes us, I will tear thy throat out villain,
unless thou instantly name him she loves.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Her Page sir, the little Christian, the good faced Captain
gave her, Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: My slave, the French Ship-boy?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I saw him leave her now. How dost thou know she loves him?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
She makes him sing bawdy songs to her, looks fortunes
in his fist, and babies in his eyes, makes dialogues betwixt
him, her little dog, and herself: lies upon her back, puts his
hand in her hand, and wrings it till the tears come again.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Insatiate monster, could her swollen blood
Reach such a height none but my Page must suit her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Contain yourself a while, this slave can speak
One of her dialogues.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
It is my practise sir: you shall stand for the Lady, you
for her dog, and I the Page: you and that dog looking
one upon another, the Page presents himself.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: The best is behind sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Jew, slave, dog.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
The horned Devil follow him. A Skippers boy?
The shame of woman? rather than be baffled thus
I will betray this town, blow up the Castle:
Francisco, do but second me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
First repossess yourself of your strong hold,
I fear some treachery: the Governor
With all the Janissaries of the town
I met in their way thither.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p:
Blast them ye powers first. The Governor
Make towards the Castle? I am betrayed, away,
I see that heaven forgets not though I delay.
Thrust out by Janissaries?

sp.speaker: Ianisa.
sp.p:
Pack hence false Runagate,
Slave, Beggar.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p:
Disgracious vassals, what mountain covers me?
Wink, wink, thou Day-star, hide my guilty shame,
Make me as if I never had been, whose name
Succeeding times will curse: should I confess my sin,
There is not an ear that can with pity hear
A man so wicked miserable: should I bear up,
Outlook my crimes, I want means to support me.
To dye I dare not, the jaws of hell do yawn
To swallow me: live I cannot: Famine threats,
And that the worst of poverty, contempt and scorn.
Never on man Fate cast so black a frown,
Up I am denied to fly, unpitied down.
Rest restless soul on this accursed soil,
And teach the world into how sad a toil
Ambition and swift riot run, when mean content
Sits low, yet happy: and when their day is spent
All that they get is labour and unrest,
A hateful grave, and worst, a troubled breast.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
Where shall I find this most unfortunate wretch?
There is a part in him called man, which we should pity
How ever his merit stands, nor will I leave him,
Though he hath left himself. See where he lies,
Best suiting with his fortunes, could we our fate foreknow
Men were as Gods, nor need we have lain so low.
How fare you brother? why with so sad an eye
Do you behold me, that in your miseries
Bear equal part?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p:
Can there remain a soul that will vouchsafe
Compassion on me? thou dost but flatter,
Or hast forgot, I have lost all, and poverty
When no ill else will do it, makes all friends fly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Were you entitled to no other guilt,
How willing for you should my blood be spilt?
Here sir, accept this poor relief
Bootless alas distress recounts those errors
To think what might have been cures, not the terrors
Of present suffering.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p:
True, true, Francisco, could I redeem the time,
The world should speak my penitence.
Could I call back but one seven years,
Though all my life were servile after,
Were my soul but free
From innocent blood, and fearful blasphemy,
On the condition I might live an age
Tortured upon a wheel.
I tell thee friend,
Were I this Cities Vice-roy, I would give
My crown, despoil myself of all, only to live
One month with that content this soul did know
When a poor Fisherman possessed it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
You are too low dejected.
Men that with sufferance their wrongs do bear
Are held but weak, and States more oft for fear
Than love unto the right, redress men's ills.
Who stoutly down his enemies, malice kills,
Who basely wounds himself.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
No less than truth, I have been too low indeed
Each one the yielding grass doth dare to tread
That flies resisting thorns, false Uoada,
Thy Lamb is turned a Lyon, I feel revenge
Give a new life to me, I will only stay
Till I have spoke thy brother, I think he will blush
To hear thy shame, tell thee thou hast not played
A woman's part with me, suppose the worse
That he turn villain to, he had better curse
His grandsires ashes, if once more I fall in
I will be unparalleled at least for sin.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Stay see the strumpets love, Fidelio,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: Captain, you are the man I seek, I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Concerning Uoada, is it not?

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
Concerning her that hates you for my sake
Neglects your merit, this night gives full revenge
To all her injuries.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Repeat that happy word again, I am wholly thine.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
Know her vassaliat lust hath long pursued,
And with such violence attempted me,
That with my oaths, this night to sate her heat
I hardly have delayed her.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: What is this to my revenge?

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
It follows, give me but way
Through your Castle there is a Hollander
This evening makes from hence
That gives them passage.
I have tied him to it.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Thou art for ever free, the hour name,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
I will speak your worth yet, in spite of fame
About three, watch the word Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Avoid suspicion and till then be gone.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: Nay then my joys do flow,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Whether tends this? what passage, come you for him?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
To heaven I once more must exact
Thy trust and diligence.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Speak it.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Make instantly to Voada, tell her
This night a skipper doth attend to steal aboard
Her love Fidelio, give her the hour and place
Wish her to pistol him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Wouldst have her kill her too.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Aye, and run made for it, mean while I will walk the
streets I shall meet some will know me to whom I will relate
my wrongs, wilt do it Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My soul to gage.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
This comfort then in spite of hell I will have,
Ward went not unrevenged unto his grave.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.p:
How black a path unbounded riot treads,
Your gentler eyes have viewed. Our Scene now leads
To give him rest, that from his ills had learned
To know his misery, and at least had earned
This lesson from the extremes, that others past
No course that violent is, secure can last.
This clue doth wind him back, and Dansiker,
The wealth of Tunis, now is become their fear,
Strives to redeem his infamy and with success,
Makes through their bowels to his happiness.
No sooner he arrives in France, but his sad ears
Instead of welcomes entertain new fears,
The aged Oak that Atlas-like sustained,
The weight of France, that with his blood regained
Her wasted body, like the Pelican
By one that from his life took breath is slain,
This fatal blow, astonisheth the hopes
Of Dansiker, and his, to make return,
Impossible those fires yet fresh do burn,
Would threaten them with utmost tortures here
To make abode, they find themselves beset
With many they by their spoil made foes, yet
Betwixt two extremes they chose the better part
Take land and to the Governor present
Themselves and fortunes, show their act, intent
And penitence, their promised pardon, what befell
This show presents, which words deny to tell.

div2.stage: Enter Gouernour in state, takes his seate, Dansiker and his followers with ropes about their neckes, their weapons with the points towards them, deliuer their petition, the Gouernour reades and salutes them, put vp their swords, suddenly rush in diuers like Merchants with followers, seeme to threaten the Gouernour, who defends Dansiker, labours betwixt them, seeme pacified, and Dansiker sweares by his sword, offer to go out to meete his wife and child, they perswade, he deliuers them to the Gouernours trust. Omnes Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.p:
Twixt hope and dread, as suited former merit,
The Governor receives them gives new spirit
Unto their drooping hopes, when with the name
Of Dansikers arrival, swift winged fame
Brings in the oppressed Merchants, whose spoil
Had fed his hungry sword, and with their toil
Made rich his rapines, these crave law, his life
The opposing Governor almost ends the strife,
With his own blood, informs them, the Kings death
Stood only bar to his safety, that his breath
Would recompense all former injuries,
To approve it gives them notice of the prise
Brought from Tunis, and more to assuage their ire
Dansiker dare, what act they can desire
Man to accomplish, to redeem his peace
And their great losses, all their furies cease.
And with one voice demand Benwash the Jew
As his just ransom, they need no more renew,
This their request, by oath themselves they tie.
to bring him prisoner, or in the action dye.
No motives from his wife or child dissuade,
This his resolve, suppose he now hath made
His back return and in some apt disguise
Attends success unto his enterprise
His end and strange prevention, briefly show
Designs are men's, their sway the gods do owe.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
This is the place a cold blood thwarts my heart,
My fleeting soul in her disturbed passion
Proclaims some ill near, let me suppose the worst
Aliziaes dead, false tongue how durst thou name
So great a mischief? alas this bracelet speaks it,
This which I tied unto her ivory wrist
The witness of those vows confirmed us one,
The news of my captivity took all her hopes
And life away, and dying she bequeathed
This loyal gift again, with my sad ransom.
It may be this youth may be Alizia
Herself a prisoner, yet she is too virtuous
To outlive her honour and her chastity,
Which her captivity must needs endanger:
I hear his footsteps.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
We are not far off from the place, softly, softly.
The night is dark and friendly to mine ends.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p: It is he would rob me of Fidelio,

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Fidelio I say young Raymond here

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p: Shoot.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: So I am slain.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p: Thus dost thou bear Fidelio back again,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
O false, false Alizia thy watch-words as thyself
Deceiving, didst think my slavery
Was not an ill sufficient, but my blood
Must pay thy falsehood tribute, or couldst not wish
So great a plague to me, that I should hear
Thou wert turned prostitute, ungentle cruel woman,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
It is not the boy sure, his voice, his passion
Speaks him another, more projects yet, I hear some foot stir.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
How fearful is the night, heaven is angry sure,
And having drawn the day up, chid her thus
For giving light to men's impieties.
It is much about the hour of my appoint,
What sad groan wounds my ears, Fidelio,
Raymond, friend Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
Or rather Infidelio, whatever thou art
Thou needst not doubt thy task, thou hast made me sure,
Or if thou doubts it, here discharge one bullet more.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
It is not his voice, thou liest false thoughts, Raymond,
Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: My name is Raymond, that Fidelio unjustly murdered.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
No marvel though thou thunderest heaven,
And darts thy flashes down, O! why is not
This world a universal fire? what one good
Keeps back thy flames?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
O speak! what art thou? whose sad speech
Makes death stay yet to hear thee.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
My friend, my Raymond by my means murdered
I have lived too long, too long.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
O speak! what art thou whose sad accents force
Pale death to stay and hear thee.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: Alas I am nothing, nothing.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: As thou hast hope in heaven tell me thy name,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
I will, my name is Alizia, thy constant loyal, loyal
friend, that in her passage unto thee will not be long

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: O save thy life.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p:
Wish me not so much ill, I love thee better.
Miracle of thy sex, O let me embrace thee yet.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Here, here, fly hence vain breath,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: No other good is known to me but death, moritur

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Francisco thou art a villain, forgiveness Voada,
The words of these two innocents with purple eyes
Dart terror through me, Fidelio turned a woman.
Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
I will rather give an ear to the black shrikes
Of mandrakes, thou knewest I loved him
And that hath forced his wound, at sight whereof
Methinks reflecting heaven should spread itself
In a deep crimson veil, blush to have created
A wretch so monstrous, but my revenge sleeps, know boy
I will repay thy death, slave I will famish thee,
And when thy fainting eye-lids gin to crack,
My satisfied lust, by him most hates thee,
Shall be thy object.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
You wrong me to suppose I should be guilty
Of such an impious deed.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
Doth not thy blood stained poniard speak it
With which thy accursed arm did force his breast
His too too gentle breast.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Thyself be witness.

div2.stage: Stabs at him, he beats it backe, and wounds her.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
That I am revenge on thee, murder, murder, the slave
will murder me.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: What mean you wife?

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p: As you are men make rescue of me.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: I am betrayed, out-gon by a she-devil.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
He hath not only slain his innocent page,
But thus assailed my life, lay hands on him
Dear countrymen revenge my wrongs, my blood
On this false runagate, I faint, I faint.
Convey me to a Surgeon, make him safe.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.p:
In the Governor's name I do command you give
your weapons up.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
'Sheart Gentlemen, you know Francisco killed him,
I will make it good.

sp.speaker: 2. Offi.
sp.p:
We have nothing to charge you with about your page
It is the wounding your wife with an unlawful weapon.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.p: You have most unmanly thrust in a woman.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Honest friends, Turks, and Officers, if ever I laid
hands on her, may I never see light more.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.p:
We will take a reasonable order for that, you never laid
hands on her, out impudence away to the dungeon with him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
'Sheart carry me to the Governor that I may have
justice first.

sp.speaker: 2. Offi.
sp.p:
The fellow raves, he thinks men in office have nothing
to do but to give him justice, you must first be punished
and then talk of justice when you have cause.

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.p:
Away with him, he shall know what it is to marry
into a great Tribe, an honourable Tribe: you use a great woman
as if she were your wife, ye are a base fellow indeed. You
a Courtier?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Nay, then I see my end draws, I shall rave,
Run mad: have you ever a Bedlam, that I may not famish
But show tricks to get meat with, or rail against the State:
And when I have eased my gall a month or two
Come out again. Zounds let me beat hemp;
Do anything rather than famish: That death
She hath vowed me, and I will prevent it: allow me
But every week a Christian, I am content
To feed upon raw flesh, if it be but once a month
A Briton, I will be content with him.

sp.speaker: 2. Offic.
sp.p: Nay then you are mad indeed, away with him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
As you are true Turks, I will put you in sureties,
I know the Devil will provide me bale,
Rather than lose my employment: as you are pitiful Turks.

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.p: Nay then we shall be troubled with you.

sp.speaker: VVard.
sp.p:
Plagues, pestilences, all fall upon my head
Rather than by a whore be famished.
I do conjure you.

div2.stage: Enter Benwash, Rabshake, at severall Doores.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Is this child of Adam coming yet? he that will
eat of the forbidden fruit though he lose Paradise for it, is
he coming.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
As fast as his legs will bear him, considering the
use he means to put them to. I have provided a Candle to
comfort him with.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
That is my dear precious villain, how sweet art thou
Revenge? the thought of thee turns all my blood to air.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And your horns too sir?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: All light Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
They were be got light, but methinks they should
be heavy in the wearing.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
I will make them abortives man, smother them in the
womb.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Though you lop the branches, you will preserve the
tree to bear more fruit, I hope, your wife sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
She shall down too, I will let her blood in a new vein
she shall turn up the white of the eye, and dye the death of a
sinner.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: How will you dispense with your oaths sir?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Tush, by equivocation man, I will not hurt her, but
thou shalt by equivocation, behind the Arras, my dear
Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
That word (by equivocation) lies on my stomach,
I would be loath it should make me cast up my gall, I would
not have my throat cut by equivocation.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: The game is roused, take thy stand and strike Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Strike you sir? you are the keeper, and have the fees in
possession, I have no money upon this equivocation.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
So the hour of my redemption is at hand, for man's
worst hell, a whore.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
You put me to a sweet purgation the other night, it was
well fear took away some of my senses, I had smelt for it
else.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: You saw the necessity of it sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
You may call it necessity. I thought of the day of
Judgment, and that was more than ever I did in my life before:
what with the fire above, and the Ram-headed Devil
your husband below, I imagined damnation could not be
far off.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Good, excellent good.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
And whither is that golden calf of Horeb, that
Jew of the the Tribe of Israel gone, that it is Jubilee with you
now, all open?

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: He is rid to the Goletto about taking in a commodity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
And in the mean time thou wilt utter one at home, I
am thy Merchant Wench, and will deal with thee by wholesale.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Rather by retail sir, retail.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Where is your Pim Rabshake, taking a nap at the stair
foot, committing sin in conceit, whilst we are at it in action?
hath he the two qualities of an Usher, a good ear, and to endure
cold of his feet? have you given him instructions?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I see how it did work, I feel it.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
He will make the old Jew believe I was his wife's
bawd.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
The slave was borne Pander, his mother was a Midwife,
and then he must needs be bawd to set his mothers trade
a work.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: You will groan for this anon sir.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: I pray you sir sit down, a small banquet sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Provocatives and whetters on? one licorous thing
draws out another. Who will not swear Venery is a sweet
sin now? Bacchus and Venus, two Gods, the Devil is far
enough off then.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: You are deceived sir, he is at your elbow.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Is Dunne in the mire? for old acquaintance sake we will
drag you out sir: you are in travel, I am the son of a Midwife,
I will help to deliver you.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: It cannot be, I am in a dream.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
A good belief doth well; were I in your case, I
should be past dreaming: but I will cast you in a slumber sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
You must be at your sweet meats: cannot Mutton
serve your turn, but you must have sauce to it?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
This Whore hath betrayed me: now she hath wrung
what she can out of me, she hangs me up for a dried Neats-tongue.
She is an insatiate Whore sir, hath enticed me by the
Pander your man: I was chaste before I knew her sir.

sp.speaker: Rabsh.
sp.p:
Believe him not sir, he is a mere Goat, look on
his beard else.

sp.speaker: Agar.
Iew.
sp.p:
I believe you wife, I believe you, and thou shalt justify
it to his teeth before the greatest Devil in hell. Rabshake
give her a Mittimus, strangle her.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Have you forgot your oaths sir?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
I swear as I was a Turk, and I will cut your throat as
I am a Jew.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Villain, keep off, I say.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: You should have said so when time was Mistress.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p:
Thou betrayest thyself slave, makest way to thine
own destruction.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Stop her throat, I say, give no ear to her.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: I do confess my sin, I have wrongfully betrayed thee.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
I find myself in bonds for it Lady, it is some comfort
yet, that I dye not unrevenged.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Thou speakest charitably. Is she gone? is her lust satisfied
now?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Do a woman to death, and she will be satisfied, nothing
else will.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Now for you Mister Gallop: you gave it me with tilting,
and I will return your courtesy.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Save my life sir, and I will be your slave, sell myself in
open market, brand me.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
That were Lextalion indeed, one mark for another:
but it will not serve the turn. Have at you.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, how the Ox gores him.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath villains, treacherous villains, the plague, pox.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
He died a true lecher, with the pox in his mouth. Why
this was valiantly done sir, in single opposition.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
why now my brow begins to smooth. How likest this
Tragedy, Rabshake?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Rarely, if it do not prove a Tragedy to us sir, it is but a
Comedy hitherto: the setting off is all.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Tush, the best is behind man: dost think I do not
bear a brain about me? Beware a politician, man: here,
bind me, bind me, hard, hard.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
Aye marry sir, I like this well, a man may trust you when
your hands are tied behind you.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
I cannot choose but laugh to think how happy I am
in my project: it will amaze thee when thou hearest it Rabshake,
we shall so gull the innocent world, laugh at the silly
world.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
If you gull me now, I will give you leave to make mummy
of me: what is next sir?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Here, take this dagger, stab mean inch into the
breast and arm.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Do you call this gulling of the world?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
I cannot but laugh at the gentleman's lecherous voyage
to Lucifer: there, there. Now Rabshake let me bind thee.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: How? bind me?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Thou art not capable of the mystery, thou art shallow
Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
I do not desire to wade deeper in I thank you sir, I am
no politician, bear no brain about me sir; yet I can dive into
a knaues pockets as well as any man, your worship knows.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: What dost thou mean by this?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
To rob you as I am a Turk, and cut your throat as I am
a Jew, you have forgot your equivocation; I will chop logic
with you. Come, your rings, your chain: do you not laugh?
have you not gulled the world fairly?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Thou hast mistaken me: know thou art all my care.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
And you would be rid of me, I conceive you sir, though
I am no politician: I have seen the play of Pedringano sir, of
Pedringano sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Dear Rabshake, upon my knees I do entreat thee hear me,
For whom have I taken thought, out-watched the night
Out-toiled the day, but for my Rabshake? what friend,
What kinsman, what heir had I but Rabshake?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Yes, you meant I should have been your heir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Nay, thou shouldst have had all in possession, my purpose
was to have lived a private life, done penance for my sins,
and given thee all.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
You would have parted with this chain, these rings
and gold.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: They are thine own, on whom should I bestow them else?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And you have a trick to come off clear with this business.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
In spite of jealousy, without suspicion man: you being
bound, your head thrust in this circle, as if tied up for starting,
I had cried out thieves, murder, raised the street, transferred
the act upon some stranger.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And I should have been your heir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Thou wrongest me to make question of it.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
If I should try him, it is beyond my compass if he
out-sail me: this chain and gold is mine.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: 'Sfoot myself too.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
For once I will try you: here bind me, if you do out-reach
me, I will never trust Jew more.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Here, here: Is thy head in?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: It is sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Have I caught you? are you in the noose? you have
seen the play of Pedringano sir, I will play with you.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
'Sheart I am your slave sir, I did it to make your worship
merry.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Tush, you are my heir, I will hang you up a airing.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: As you are a man hear me sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
You must have your chains, you shall be chained, I
could even crack my sides with laughter. This will afford
me mirth unto my dying day. The play of Pedringano? how
the weezle hangs! Ha, ha, ha. Thieves, thieves: Murder, murder.
I shall betray myself with laughter. Were you caught
Rynard? are you in the noose? Murder, murder, thieves murder.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Break ope the doors, the voice speaks from this
room.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: Inhumane deed! what hand could be so bloody?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Speak, who was the murderer?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Help me to a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p:
Run for a Surgeon. Tell by what monster was this
act (so full of horror) done?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Three strangers rushed in suddenly, we being at supper,
all my servants forth, save honest Rabshake: and having rifled
us, did act this horrid murther.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Here is a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: The Prophet Mahomet reveal the homicides.

div2.stage: Enter Gouernor, other officers, Sare, Ferd. Alb. Dansiker disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.p: What moves these out-cries?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Behold a bloody murder, Benwash, his wife,
This Captain, and his servant.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: My honest servant, honest Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: Benwash murdered? he hath saved me a labour.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Is there any hope of life in him?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p:
His wounds are sleight sir, only his faint-heart makes
them dangerous.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Take courage man, Speak, hast thou any knowledge
of the Murderers?

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: Only he says they are strangers, men of the sea.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Canst thou remember in what habit, what men of person
and complexion they were?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: What means the slave to eye me so?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: That fellow in the stammel hose is one of them.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
On me? Villain, thou buyest my blood
At a dear rate. O thou immortal God
Who knowest my innocence! that for his former sins
Hast given up Dansiker into the hands
Of these damned miscreants.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
I Dansiker, that would with all your deaths
Have cancelled his former infamy,
Left to the world a president of valour,
Writ in your sad confusions: but heaven is just,
Christians did fall by me, by slaves I must.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Call forth the common Hangman, by this time he hath
done his office on Francisco, Dansiker? unlooked for?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Hear me before I dye, I do confess
Mine own hand did these murthers. Dansiker
Hath justly done me vengeance.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
How is this? thou done these murthers thyself, being
bound and hurt? Thou ravest sure.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
I did them sir: the cause my wife proved false, untrue,
Bear witness, though I lived a Turk, I dye a Jew.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Out Dog, Devil.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Unheard of Monster! Cast his loathed carcass
Unto the common air. Never did day discover
Two such inhumane Caitiffs, stretch out his arms,
You have your trains and fireworks, apply your Torches
Unto his breast. We will; know what project now
Lead you unto this second venture.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
I will confess it willingly: It was to have conveyed
This Jew from hence, have made a massacre
Of the whole Town, dashed out the miscreant brains
Of your young Infidels.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: And art not sorry, Dog?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
Yes Dog, I am sorry, and confess my crimes
Prevented such a merit: I was not worthy
To do heaven so good a service.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Pull off his hateful flesh, dig out his heart
by piecemeal.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: Wilt thou turn Turk, and save thy soul yet?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p:
Yes Pagan, villain, I will. Forgiveness heaven,
Let my example move all Pirates, Robbers
To think how heavy thy revenging hand.
Will sit upon them. I feel thy justice now,
Receive my soul, accept my intended vow.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
So, convey his hateful body to the same place,
The Jew doth lie unburied.

div2.stage: Enter at seuerall doores Voad and Ward.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: Justice, let me have Justice, worthy Governor.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Give her no ear, she is all woman dissimulation.
I am a Turk, and I do crave the law.

sp.speaker: Turk.
sp.p:
He hath wounded here a Turk, a Lady, and
We crave sentence according to his merit.
He may receive the Bastinado, pay a fine.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Pay a fine, what fine, from one that is famished,
For want of a poor asper, set me to sea again,
The tenth of what I will bring you in, shall countervail
The revenue of the Indies.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p:
The slave is mad, we will send you far enough,
Lady depose thee for it, you shall have justice.

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p: By our great Prophet Mahomet.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
You do me wrong, let me in private speak to her
Ere she betray my life, it is no less
Than your own law affords me.

sp.speaker: Turk.
sp.p: The weakness of her body brooks it not.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p: How say you Voada, can you afford him speech?

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p:
I will give his vain words hearing, though to much pain
O my deep wound let all remove from hence.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Had she a heart of brass I would pierce it, leave us all.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: Now sir your motion,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Wherein hath my desert strowed so much ill
To strain thy hate, to this a high beyond,
What we seem malice, I loved that face so well
To purchase it I exchanged my heaven with hell.
And to be barred what I so dearly paid for,
Is it not a plague sufficient? but thy faith
Must now be sold, to be a vengeance greater,
To pay me ungrateful hire, canst thou behold
These eyes stroke inward, as ashamed to view
The fires which first betrayed them, this mind, body,
That doth contain a soul more black and dismal
Than is the raven night, these arms, that have so oft
Made to thee rules of love, now famished
For want of what thou surfeits on, canst without tears
Behold my miseries?

sp.speaker: Uoad.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Prodigy of woman, dost laugh?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p:
This is true music, could I enjoy these tunes
Myself would be thy Jailer.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Why then thy wound is not dangerous?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p:
A mere scratch, know that I am revenged
Of my Fidelios death, and as thy tortures
Each hour increase, so shall my harmony
Till vengeance period give unto thy destiny.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: I will discover thy hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: You are prevented, help, I found, I fall.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: As low as hell there keep thy festival.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p:
Hold murderous villain, all tortures man everknew,
Shall be inflicted on thee.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Inhumane dog.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, I laugh at you.
Here is a preservative, against all your poisons
True Balsamum for villainy, who will soar high
First lesson that he learns, must be to dye.
Here is precedent for him, you are slaves of Mahomet
Ungrateful curs, that have repaid me thus
For all the service that I have done for you,
He that hath brought more treasure to your shore
Than all Arabia yields, he that hath shown you
The way to conquer Europe, did first impart,
What your forefathers knew not, the seaman's art;
Which had they attained, this universe had been
One Monarchy: may all your seed be damned
The name of Ottoman be the only scorn
And by-word to all Nations; may his own slaves
Tear out the bowels of the last remains
Unto his blood-propped throne, may ye cut each others throat:
Or may, O may the force of Christendom
Be reunited, and all at once require
The lives of all that you have murdered,
Beating a path out to Ierusalem,
Over the bleeding breasts of you and yours.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Unheard of monster.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p:
Lastly, O may I be the last of all my country
That trust unto your treacheries, seducing treacheries,
All you that live by theft and Piracies,
That sell your lives and souls to purchase graves,
That dye to hell, and live far worse than slaves,
Let dying Ward tell you that heaven is just,
And that despair attends on blood and lust:

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: down with the villain.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.p:
Tear the wretch piecemeal, throw his accursed limbs
Into the raging bowels of the sea.
His monument in brass we will thus engrave,
Ward sold his country, turned Turk, and died a slave.
